ygData.subject: Re: Benchmarks?
ygData.msgSnippet: Actually it is generally started with the poles in the position you stated, and not from random initial states.  There s no particular reason for doing it that

Actually it is generally started with the poles in the position you 
stated, and not from random initial states.  There's no particular 
reason for doing it that way or not doing it that way; it's 
basically just historical precedent.  But since the point is to be 
able to compare methods with a benchmark, it doesn't really matter 
how you're running the experiment as long as it's consistent.

That said, people have thought about the brittleness of starting 
from a single point, and in fact that's one of the reason's for 
Gruau's special fitness function.  Also you will notice in reports 
on DPBNV starting with Gruau, they usually report a generalization 
performance measure, which is taken by starting the champion network 
at literally hundreds of different start states and seeing if it can 
balance for over 1000 time steps from each state.  Usually 
controllers that do well on Gruau's fitness function can handle at 
around 1/3 to 1/2 of all the spectrum of 625 different possible 
starting states, which is not bad considering it wasn't trained on 
them directly.  In fact, it shows the controllers are often not so 
brittle after all.

Now, a separate line of research concerns how to make the task 
increasingly difficult.  And requiring more generalization is one 
way to go.  But it's not really that attractive since it mean a lot 
more computation dedicated to testing from all those start states.  
Instead, most researchers who have looked for harder DBP tasks have 
changed the relative lengths of the poles.  Changing them to become 
closer in length makes the task harder and harder.  In fact, it 
becomes extremely hard very quickly to the point where only 
incremental evolution can handle it.  (If you want to go down this 
route, Faustino Gomez from our group published on a principled way 
of changing pole lengths...I'd look for that paper, rather than just 
try arbitrary pole lengths since most ratios will be next to 
impossible)

Anyway, I hope that gives some perspective on your questions.

ken


--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Derek James <djames@g...> wrote:
> Okay, so we've implemented Double Pole Balancing and DPB with no
> velocities input into the network.  And ANJI is solving them fine,
> with both Ken's mutation operators and with ours.  We haven't quite
> implemented the No Wiggling penalty, but are about to do that.
> 
> One question we had was this: Were all experiments with double pole
> balancing started from the same, deterministic state?  That is, 
with
> one pole at 0 degrees (upright), and the other leaning at exactly 1
> degree?
> 
> Since we hadn't implemented the domain before, we hadn't really
> thought about it much, but wouldn't it be fairly easy to scale up 
the
> difficulty of this domain by randomizing the initial starting
> conditions?  That is, have the poles start at random initial
> positions?
> 
> If we're evolving a controller, this thing would be extremely 
brittle
> if it only learned to balance poles from a single starting 
position,
> wouldn't it?
> 
> By extension, the initial cart position could also be randomized.  
The
> controllers could be given a small amount of noise.  There could 
also
> be "wind" or some other sort of noise added to the system to scale 
up
> difficulty.
> 
> Is anyone aware of this being done with any of the previous pole
> balancing work?  If not, why?
> 
> Derek
